project_name: Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) on Ring road of Kathmandu
project_short_description: This is a Zero-Emission Urban transport project.
project_description:
The Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) project on the Ring Road of Kathmandu is a significant public transportation initiative aimed at modernizing and improving the efficiency of the city's transit system. Spanning 27.3 kilometers around the Kathmandu Valley, this project will establish a dedicated bus lane designed to alleviate the heavy traffic congestion that plagues the city. The primary goal is to provide a reliable, efficient, and eco-friendly mode of transportation for the residents of Kathmandu, enhancing the overall public transport infrastructure.

The BRT project is being implemented under the Build-Operate-Transfer (BOT) model, which involves private sector participation in the development, operation, management, and maintenance of the system. The introduction of electric buses is a key component of the project, aligning with broader environmental goals to reduce air pollution and promote sustainable urban mobility. The system will feature modern facilities, including state-of-the-art bus stops and an efficient ticketing system, ensuring a smooth and convenient experience for passengers.

This project is not just about deploying electric vehicles on existing roads; it also includes significant improvements to the current road infrastructure to accommodate the dedicated bus lanes. This will ensure that the BRT buses can operate without interference from other vehicular traffic, significantly reducing travel times and improving punctuality. The project ultimately aims to transform Kathmandu's public transportation landscape by providing a fast, reliable, and environmentally friendly alternative to traditional modes of transport.

project_name: Solar street lights being replaced with traditional ones
project_short_description: This project replaces solar street lights with smart electric street lights. Electric bulbs of 90 and 120 watt capacities are being installed.
project_description:
Authorities concerned hoped that the solar lights would be economical in the long run, even if the initial investment for installing them costs higher, and also reduce the electricity tariff.

Officials at the Kathmandu metropolis, however, said that along with advantages, solar lights also have its drawbacksâ€”limited brightness, limited battery life and need to clean up the panel frequently due to excessive dust during the dry season.

Kathmandu Metropolitan City (KMC) has installed 1,026 smart 'street lights' at various places in the capital city.

Among them, 318 lights have been installed in Maharajganj-Lainchaur-Jamal section, 363 in the Maharajgunj National Police Academy-Baluwatar-Naxal-Maitighar Mandala route, 181 from Kamalpokhari to Gaushala, 76 along the Tripureshwor-Thapathali-Maitighar Mandala road, and 99 in Chabahil-Boudha road section.
